div.l: ¶ Here bigynneth þe prologe of þe Cook
The Cook of londoıı̄un while þe Reue spak
For ioye hym thoughte he clawed hym on þe bak
A ha quod he for cristes passioıı̄un
This meller hath a sharp conclusioıı̄un
Vpon his argument of herbergage
Wel seide Salamon in his langage
Ne bringe not eủery man in to thyn hous
For herberwyng by nyghte is ꝑperilous
Wel oughte a man auysed for to be
Whom þat he broughte in to his pⁱriuete
I preye to god so ȝeue me sorwe ⁊and care
Ȝif euere sitthen I highte hogge of ware
Herde I meller bet yset a werke
He hadde a iape of malice in þe derke
And þ̉erfore ȝif ȝe vouchesauf to here
But god forbede þᵗat we stynte here
A tale of me þat am a pore man
I wol ȝow telle as wel as eủere I can
A litel iape þᵗat fil in oure Cite
Oure oost answerde and seide I gᵃraunte it þe
Now telle on Roger loke þat it be good
For many a paste hast þou laten blood
And many a Iakke of douere hast þou sold
That hath been twies hoot and twies cold
Of many a pilgryme hast þou curs
For of thy ꝑpersile ȝit þei fare þe wors
That þei have eten with thy stubbil goos
For in þi schoppe is many a flye loos
Now telle on gentil Roger by þi name
But ȝit I pray þe by not wroth for game
A man may say ful soth in game and pley
Thou seist ful soth quod Roger by my fey
But soth pley quade pley / as þe flemyng seith
And therfore herry Baily by thy feith
Be þou nouȝt wroth er we departen here
Though þat my tale be of an Ostellere
But natheles I wol not telle it ȝit
Bur er we parte ywis þou shalt be quit
